text:
Aldric of Le Mans

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to navigation Jump to search
This article needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.
Find sources: "Aldric of Le Mans" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR (April 2020) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)
Saint Aldric
Bornc. 800
Died(856-01-07)7 January 856.
Le Mans
Venerated inRoman Catholicism

Saint Aldric (c. 800 – 7 January 856) was Bishop of Le Mans in the time of Louis the Pious.

Contents

  • 1 Life
  • 2 References
  • 3 Relevant works
  • 4 Further reading

Life[edit]

Aldric was born of a noble family, of partly Saxon and partly Bavarian extraction, about the year 800. At the age of twelve he was placed by his father in the court of Charlemagne, in the household of his son Louis the Pious at Aix la Chapelle. Aldric was highly esteemed by both monarchs, but at the age of twenty-one he withdrew to Metz and became a priest. He was then recalled to the court by Louis, who took him as his chaplain and the guide of his conscience.[1]

Nine years after his ordination, Aldric was made Bishop of Le Mans. He was consecrated on the 22nd of December. The emperor arrived at Mans three days after, and kept the Christmas holy-days with him.[2] He was a learned and pious prelate, devoted to the poor and to the religious interests of his Diocese.[3] Apart from being conspicuously virtuous, he showed a practical turn in building aqueducts and ransoming captives, as well as building new churches and restoring monasteries.[1]

In the civil wars which followed the death of Louis, Aldric's loyalty to Charles the Bald resulted in his expulsion from his see, and he withdrew to Rome. Gregory IV reinstated him. In 836, as an emissary of the Council of Aix la Chapelle Aldric visited Pepin I, who was then King of Aquitaine, with Erchenrad, Bishop of Paris, and persuaded Pepin to order that all the possessions of the Church which had been seized by his followers should be restored.[1]

Aldric's episcopate lasted for twenty-four years, and during his lifetime he took part in the Councils of Paris in 846 and Tours in 849. The two last years of his life he was confined to his bed by a palsy. He died at Le Mans on 7 January 856 and was buried in the church of Saint Vincent, having been bishop for twenty-four years.[2]

He was succeeded by Robert.

References[edit]

  1. ^ a b c Campbell, Thomas. "St. Aldric." The Catholic Encyclopedia Vol. 1. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1907. 12 April 2020 This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the public domain.
  2. ^ a b Butler, Alban. "Saint Aldric, Bishop of Mans, Confessor". Lives of the Fathers, Martyrs, and Principal Saints, 1866. CatholicSaints.Info. 6 January 2013 This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the public domain.
  3. ^ Monks of Ramsgate. "Aldericus". Book of Saints, 1921. CatholicSaints.Info. 18 May 2012 This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the public domain.

 This article incorporates text from a publication now in the public domain: Campbell, Thomas Joseph (1907). "St. Aldric". In Herbermann, Charles (ed.). Catholic Encyclopedia. 1. New York: Robert Appleton Company.

Relevant works[edit]

  • Actus Pontificum Cenomannis (in urbe degentium), compiled during Aldric's episcopate.
    • ed. Margarete Weidemann, Geschichte des Bistums Le Mans von der Spätantike bis zur Karolingerzeit: Actus Pontificum Cenomannis in urbe degentium und Gesta Aldrici. 3 vols. Mainz, 2000.
  • Gesta (Domni) Aldrici, which relates how Aldric translated the bodies of the saints and former bishops of Le Mans: Julianus, Turibius, Pavatius, Romanus, Liborius and Hadoindus to his cathedral.
    • ed. Margarete Weidemann, Geschichte des Bistums Le Mans von der Spätantike bis zur Karolingerzeit: Actus Pontificum Cenomannis in urbe degentium und Gesta Aldrici. 3 vols. Mainz, 2000.

Further reading[edit]

  • Goffart, Walter A. The Le Mans forgeries: a chapter from the history of church property in the ninth century. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard UP, 1966. Contents.
